teas101.title: Introduction to Tea Appreciation
teas101.prerequisites: A love for hot beverages and a willingness to sip with sophistication.
teas101.restrictions: Coffee enthusiasts may experience FOMO (Fear of Missing Out).
teas101.description: TEAS 101 is designed for students who want a university-level introduction to the world of tea. Topics covered include the history of tea, different types of tea (black, green, yellow, oolong, and pu'er), and the fine art of tea brewing. Students will learn to distinguish between 'a good cuppa' and 'leaf juice'. Assignments will include tasting sessions and creating your own blend, with a strong emphasis on pinky finger elevation while sipping.

teas102.title: Herbal Tea and Wellness
teas102.prerequisites: None, but an affinity for natural remedies is a plus.
teas102.restrictions: Those allergic to peppermint may discuss alternatives with the HoS.
teas102.description: TEAS 103 introduces students to the soothing world of herbal teas. Topics include the health benefits of chamomile, peppermint, and ginger teas, as well as how to craft your own herbal infusions. Students will participate in 'herbal hunts' to gather ingredients and will learn the secret recipe for 'Sleepy Time Potion' – guaranteed to make even the most restless insomniac doze off. The course culminates in a 'Wellness Tea Fair' where students showcase their own herbal blends.

teas103.title: Introduction to Gong Fu Tea
teas103.prerequisites: None, but an appreciation for tea culture is recommended.
teas103.description: TEAS 103 introduces students to the art of Gong Fu tea. Topics include the history of Cha, the importance of mindfulness in tea preparation, and an overview of essential tea utensils. Students will contrast the practice of using gaiwans and yixing teapots, mastering the delicate balance of minerality, aromatics, astringency in the brewing process. The course culminates in a 'High Tea' session where students compete in categories like 'Most Graceful Pour' and 'Best Aroma Appreciation Slurp.'

teas242.title: Advanced Tea Blending
teas242.prerequisites: TEAS 101 or a demonstrated ability to take tea without sugar or milk.
teas242.restrictions: Teabag enthusiasts may find this course challenging.
teas242.description: TEAS 202 delves deeper into the science and artistry of blending teas. Students will explore advanced techniques in combining different tea leaves, herbs, and spices to create harmonious and unique blends. The course includes field trips to tea plantations, where students will practice 'the tea leaf shuffle' – a dance believed to bring good luck to the harvest. Final projects involve creating a blend that pairs perfectly with sweet or savoury snacks.

teas202.title: Advanced Gong Fu Techniques
teas202.restrictions: Teaware with capacity greater than 200 mL
teas202.description: TEAS 204 takes students deeper into the nuances of Gong Fu tea preparation. Focus areas include mastering the use of the gong dao bei (fairness pitcher) and cha ze (tea scoop), as well as perfecting the art of multiple infusions. Students will explore the subtle differences between Dan Cong and Pu'er teas, and learn to adjust brewing techniques accordingly. The course includes a field trip to a farm in Yunnan, where students will pick their own leaves and attempt to replicate the farm's signature brew back in the lab.

teas204.title: Tea and Literature
teas204.prerequisites: TEAS 101 and a love for reading while sipping tea.
teas204.restrictions: None, but a distaste for Earl Grey may affect enjoyment of some readings.
teas204.description: TEAS 204 explores the role of tea in classic and contemporary literature. Students will analyze tea scenes in novels, poems, and plays, and discuss how tea has influenced literary culture. The course includes 'Tea and Book Club' sessions where students pair different teas with their favorite books. Highlights include a dramatic reading of 'Alice in Wonderland' with a tea party reenactment and a special lecture on 'The Mystery of the Missing Tea Cup' in Agatha Christie's novels.

teas301.title: Tea and Culture: A Global Perspective
teas301.prerequisites: TEAS 202 and a passport ready for tea world travel.
teas301.restrictions: Participants must not have any strong aversions to unglazed clay.
teas301.description: TEAS 301 explores the cultural significance of tea around the world. From the Japanese tea ceremony to Russian afternoon tea, students will learn how different cultures have embraced this beloved beverage. Special emphasis will be placed on the ancient art of reading tea leaves, and watching water boil. The course includes daily physical exercises with clay and cast iron kettles.'

teas302.title: How to Train you Tea Pet
teas302.prerequisites: TEAS 204 and a sense of familiarity with inanimate objects.
teas302.restrictions: Students must provide their own familiar/gargoyle.
teas302.description: TEAS 305 delves into the whimsical world of tea pets and their role in Gong Fu tea ceremonies. Students will learn the history and symbolism of tea pets, and how to properly 'train' them through repeated tea pouring. The course includes creative assignments like crafting personalized bedtime stories for their tea pets and participating in a 'Tea Pet Show and Tell.' Additionally, students will study the cultural significance of Gong Fu Cha, exploring how it reflects and shapes social interactions and personal mindfulness.

teas305.title: Tea Etiquette and Diplomacy
teas305.restrictions: Students prone to spilling tea may need extra napkins.
teas305.description: TEAS 305 delves into the refined world of tea etiquette and its role in diplomacy. Students will learn proper tea-serving techniques, the art of the tea toast, and how to handle delicate teacups without chipping them. The course includes role-playing scenarios where students must navigate complex diplomatic situations over tea. The final exam is a 'Diplomatic Tea Summit' where students must resolve an international crisis brewing in a teacup.

teas401.title: Tea Chemistry and Innovations
teas401.description: TEAS 401 is an advanced course that explores the chemistry of tea and modern innovations in tea production. Students will study the chemical compounds responsible for tea's flavour and health benefits, and experiment with new brewing technologies. The course includes lab sessions where students create 'super teas' with enhanced flavors and benefits. Highlights include a visit from a leading tea scientist and a 'Tea Innovation Fair'.

teas402.title: Tea Sommelier Training
teas402.prerequisites: TEAS 301 or the ability to distinguish Earl Grey from Lady Grey in a blind taste test.
teas402.description: TEAS 402 is the pinnacle of tea education, training students for their journey to become professional tea sommeliers. Coursework includes advanced tea tasting techniques, the chemistry of tea, and the art of pairing tea with food. Students will be expected to develop a tea menu for a five-star restaurant and pass a rigorous 'tea sommelier certification exam,' which includes identifying the origin of a tea by smell alone.

teas403.title: The Chemistry of Pu'er and Dan Cong Teas
teas403.prerequisites: TEAS 305 and a curiosity for the science behind aging.
teas403.restrictions: None, but students with a fear of aging may find some topics unsettling.
teas403.description: TEAS 401 offers an in-depth exploration of the chemical processes that give Pu'er and Dan Cong teas their unique characteristics. Students will study the fermentation and aging processes of Pu'er, and the distinctive floral and fruity notes of Dan Cong oolongs. The course includes lab sessions where students will age their own tea samples and conduct taste tests to observe flavor evolution. Guest lectures from renowned tea chemists will provide insights into the latest research and innovations in tea processing.

teas502.title: Masterclass in Tea Ceremonies
teas502.restrictions: Students must wear white gloves during ceremonies to avoid fingerprints.
teas502.description: TEAS 502 offers an in-depth study of traditional tea ceremonies from around the world. Students will master the intricate rituals of Japanese, Chinese, and Morrocan tea ceremonies, learning the significance of each gesture and component. The course includes guest appearances from renowned tea masters and a chance to perform a tea ceremony for visiting dignitaries. The final project is a 'Global Tea Ceremony Showcase' where students demonstrate their proficiency in multiple tea traditions, aiming to achieve the perfect brew every time.

teas504.title: Masterclass in Gong Fu Tea Ceremonies
teas504.restrictions: Students must wear traditional tea attire during ceremonies.
teas504.description: TEAS 504 is a masterclass dedicated to perfecting the Gong Fu tea ceremony. Students will refine their skills in using yixing teapots and other utensils with precision and grace. The course covers advanced pouring techniques, the choreography of tea ceremonies, and the subtle art of creating the perfect tea environment. The final project is a 'Gong Fu Tea Showcase,' where students will perform a full tea ceremony for an audience, demonstrating their mastery of both technical skills and the cultural essence of Gong Fu Cha.

heat145.title: Introduction to Heat Dynamics
heat145.prerequisites: A curiosity for thermodynamics and basic science knowledge.
heat145.description: HEAT 145 introduces students to the fascinating world of heat transfer and thermodynamics. Topics include the principles of heat conduction, convection, and radiation, with real-world applications in cooking, engineering, and climate studies. Students will engage in hands-on experiments to demonstrate heat flow and explore the impact of heat on different materials. The course includes lab sessions and a final project exploring heat-related phenomena.

heat101.title: Fundamentals of Heat and Energy
heat101.prerequisites: Basic understanding of physics is helpful.
heat101.description: HEAT 101 covers the essential concepts of heat and energy, including energy sources, transformation processes, and the role of heat in daily life. Students will investigate how energy is harnessed, used, and conserved, with a particular focus on sustainable energy practices. This course includes both theoretical lessons and practical lab experiments.

clay101.title: Introduction to Clay Artistry
clay101.description: CLAY 101 is an entry-level course that introduces students to the art of working with clay. Topics covered include basic pottery techniques, the properties of clay, and the tools used in shaping and firing. Students will create their own pieces using hand-building and wheel-throwing methods, culminating in a small clay exhibition.

cups102.title: Ceramic Cups and Vessels
cups102.description: CUPS 102 focuses on the design and creation of ceramic cups and other small vessels. Students will learn about different clay types, glazing techniques, and firing methods to craft functional, yet artistic, pieces. The course will include both guided lessons and independent work, with a final project that features personalized cup designs.

heat142.title: Thermal Energy and Efficiency
heat142.description: HEAT 142 delves deeper into thermal energy and its efficient use. The course covers energy transfer mechanisms, heat pumps, and practical applications for optimizing energy consumption. Students will engage in case studies on energy efficiency in buildings and industrial processes. The course includes a project on improving energy use in a real-world scenario.

leaf142.title: Introduction to Leaf Identification
leaf142.description: LEAF 142 introduces students to the art and science of leaf identification. Topics covered include the identification of common trees and shrubs by their leaves, the anatomy of leaves, and their role in plant ecology. Fieldwork will be a key component, with students documenting leaf samples from different environments. The course culminates in a field identification test.

clay102.title: Advanced Clay Techniques
clay102.description: CLAY 102 builds on the skills learned in CLAY 101, focusing on more advanced pottery techniques. Students will explore more complex forms, including lidded jars, sculptures, and decorative glazing techniques. The course also covers kiln firing techniques and teaches students how to manage the entire ceramic process from start to finish.

leaf151.title: Plants and the Environment
leaf151.description: LEAF 151 explores the relationship between plants and their environments. Students will study plant growth, ecosystems, and the environmental challenges plants face in a changing world. The course includes field trips and practical activities aimed at observing plant species in different habitats. The final project will involve researching the effects of climate change on local flora.

heat243.title: Thermodynamics of Heat Engines
heat243.description: HEAT 243 focuses on the thermodynamics behind heat engines. Students will learn about the fundamental laws of thermodynamics, engine cycles, and the design of heat engines. Practical labs will include constructing simple engines and measuring their efficiency. This course is essential for students pursuing a career in mechanical engineering or energy systems.

heat245.title: Renewable Heat and Energy Systems
heat245.description: HEAT 245 introduces students to renewable energy sources, including solar thermal, geothermal, and biomass heat systems. Topics include the design, implementation, and efficiency of renewable heat systems. Students will engage in projects focused on creating models of sustainable energy systems for homes and businesses.

data202.title: Data Analysis for Heat Systems
data202.prerequisites: Basic knowledge of data science or completion of introductory statistics.
data202.description: DATA 202 is a practical course designed to teach students how to analyze and interpret data related to heat systems. Students will learn to use statistical tools and software to process and visualize energy consumption, heat transfer efficiency, and temperature data. The course includes hands-on work with real-world datasets.

gaiw231.title: Global Agriculture and Heat Impacts
gaiw231.description: GAIW 231 explores the relationship between agriculture and climate change, with a specific focus on heat stress impacts on crops. Students will analyze case studies on global food production, temperature extremes, and agricultural practices. The course includes fieldwork to examine the resilience of local crops under varying heat conditions.

leaf244.title: Advanced Leaf Ecology
leaf244.description: LEAF 244 builds on basic plant biology and ecology, with a deeper exploration of leaf morphology and physiology. Students will study how leaves adapt to different climates and environments. The course includes field research and laboratory work, with students conducting experiments on leaf growth under different conditions.

heat241.title: Heat in Industrial Systems
heat241.description: HEAT 241 focuses on the application of heat in industrial settings. Topics include industrial heating methods, heat exchangers, and heat management in large-scale production environments. Students will work on case studies and simulations of heat optimization in manufacturing processes.

heat242.title: Energy Recovery and Storage
heat242.description: HEAT 242 explores techniques for recovering and storing energy from heat sources. Students will study energy storage methods, such as thermal batteries and phase change materials, and how to integrate these systems into energy grids. The course includes lab sessions where students design their own energy recovery prototypes.

clay201.title: Advanced Ceramics and Sculpture
clay201.description: CLAY 201 is designed for students who wish to explore the artistic side of ceramics and sculpture. The course covers advanced techniques in clay shaping, including sculptural forms, glazing, and firing methods. Students will create large-scale ceramic sculptures and installations, culminating in a group exhibition.

stem215.title: STEM and Sustainable Energy Solutions
stem215.description: STEM 215 provides students with an interdisciplinary approach to sustainable energy. Topics include solar, wind, and geothermal energy systems, energy efficiency, and environmental impacts. The course includes hands-on projects, guest lectures from industry professionals, and field trips to renewable energy sites.

heat305.title: Advanced Thermodynamics
heat305.description: HEAT 305 is a deep dive into advanced thermodynamics, focusing on complex heat systems and non-equilibrium thermodynamics. Students will apply these principles to analyze systems such as power plants, refrigeration units, and climate modeling. The course includes a capstone project on an advanced thermodynamic application.

heat307.title: Heat Transfer in Engineering
heat307.description: HEAT 307 examines heat transfer mechanisms in engineering applications. Topics include conduction, convection, radiation, and heat exchangers, with a focus on their application in industrial processes. Students will work on case studies and design projects related to heat transfer in real-world systems.

clay301.title: Ceramic Sculptures and Large-Scale Works
clay301.description: CLAY 301 focuses on the creation of large-scale ceramic sculptures and installations. Students will explore advanced techniques in clay forming, surface treatment, and firing. The course includes working with industrial kilns and experimenting with alternative firing methods to achieve artistic effects.

clay360.title: Contemporary Ceramics and Design
clay360.description: CLAY 360 introduces students to contemporary ceramic art and design, exploring cutting-edge techniques and trends. Students will focus on conceptual design, mixed media, and experimental approaches to ceramics. The course culminates in a solo exhibition where students present their innovative works.

heat304.title: Thermodynamic Systems Analysis
heat304.description: HEAT 304 provides students with the tools to analyze complex thermodynamic systems. The course covers system modeling, optimization techniques, and the application of thermodynamics to modern engineering problems. Students will work on real-world case studies to analyze energy systems and their efficiency.

heat345.title: Heat and Environmental Impact
heat345.description: HEAT 345 explores the environmental impact of heat-related energy systems. Topics include greenhouse gas emissions, energy conservation, and the role of heat in climate change. Students will participate in group projects focusing on the reduction of carbon footprints in industrial and domestic heating systems.

stem315.title: STEM capstone course
stem315.description: STEM 315 provides a comprehensive look at advanced renewable energy systems. Topics include wind, solar, tidal, and geothermal energy, with a focus on innovative technologies and their application. The course includes fieldwork and group projects aimed at designing renewable energy solutions for the future.

leaf321.title: Forest Ecology and Heat
leaf321.description: LEAF 321 examines the relationship between forests and temperature regulation. Students will study forest ecosystems, carbon sequestration, and how trees mitigate the urban heat island effect. The course includes fieldwork in local forests and a final project that explores how forests can be managed to mitigate climate change.
